discharge_summary: admission: 12/11/2020, discharge: 01/23/2021, stay: 01 m 11 d 10 h, location: ward, payer: sus [person], 28 years old, from [address] 12/14 weight: 102 kg height: 162 cm. problem: 1 Status epilepticus secondary to pulmonary infection Phenytoin attack performed and maintenance dose of PHT increased Pb dosage maintained Dosage of other drugs LTG, TPM and CLB 2 Sepsis pulmonary focus 3 Deep vein thrombosis Right lower limb Full dose of enoxaparin started on 12/23 4 Pseudomembranous colitis Metronidazole started 12/30 01/10 5 Adrenal insufficiency secondary to sepsis Hydrocortisone 50 mg every 12h started on 12/31 Weaning started on 01/10 Previous functionality Oral diet Walked without assistance Dependent for some instrumental activities of daily living Bathing, physiological eliminations. Tests: Electroencephalogram 12/12: Mild to moderate disorganization of baseline activity due to increased slow wave content in the theta and delta bands, but with the presence of normal sleep graphoelements. There was no clinical or electrographic reactivity to nociceptive stimulation. b Record of electrographic seizures of variable duration (4 to 9 seconds), characterized by rhythmic activity in the beta range, evolving to alpha and theta ranges, associated with spike-type epileptiform paroxysms, with generalized projection, without associated clinical phenomena. There was a record of a seizure with rhythmic evolution to the delta range and of longer duration (18 seconds). Rare spike-type paroxysms were recorded, occurring isolatedly in the left frontocentral region. Clinical correlation: The findings are consistent with focal epilepsy with electrographic seizures, but do not characterize status epilepticus. electroencephalogram 12/19: marked symmetrical disorganization of the background activity due to persistent rhythmic, semi-rhythmic bifrontal slowing in the delta band, at approximately 1.5 Hz, of medium amplitude, only temporarily mitigated by nociceptive stimulation; furthermore, lack and poor definition of physiological graphoelements of sleep. Upon nociceptive stimulation, there is also a triggering of generalized rhythmic epileptiform activity in the beta band, of low voltage, which evolves into an outbreak of frank epileptiform paroxysms of the spike type followed by a slow wave, also of diffuse expression, and with bifrontal accentuation of such stimulus-induced discharges, suppression of the clinical tracing follows; [person] presents only with painful facies. b Occasionally, associated with the slow waves described above, bisynchronous epileptiform paroxysms of the sharp wave type are observed, involving the anterior regions of the scalp. Conclusion and electroclinical correlation: the electroencephalogram was abnormal. The findings are compatible with severe diffuse encephalopathy of a nonspecific nature, associated with focal and generalized interictal epileptogenesis, the latter being stimulus-induced. Electroencephalogram 12/22: a moderate symmetrical disorganization of the background activity due to an increase in the content of slow waves in the theta and delta bands, in addition to a lack and poor definition of the physiological graphoelements of sleep. However, good electroencephalographic reactivity is noted in response to nociceptive stimuli, with an association with a dominant posterior rhythmic outline in the alpha band. b bursts of generalized rhythmic delta activity (grda) with bifrontal accentuation, occurring intermittently throughout the tracing during sleep, consisting of stereotyped waves in the 2.0 to 2.5 Hz band. Electroencephalogram 12/22: a moderate symmetrical disorganization of the background activity due to an increase in the content of slow waves in the theta and delta bands, in addition to a lack and poor definition of the physiological graphoelements of sleep. However, good electroencephalographic reactivity is noted in response to nociceptive stimuli, with an association with a dominant posterior rhythmic outline in the alpha band. b bursts of generalized rhythmic delta activity (grda) with bifrontal accentuation, occurring intermittently throughout the tracing during sleep, consisting of stereotyped waves in the 2.0 to 2.5 Hz band. Conclusion and electroclinical correlation: the electroencephalogram was abnormal. The findings are compatible with moderate diffuse encephalopathy, of a nonspecific nature in relation to the previous tracing; significant improvement is noted, with mitigation of grda and suppression of stimulus-induced generalized epileptogenesis. electroencephalogram 02/01: slight symmetrical disorganization of the baseline activity due to the slowing of the dominant posterior rhythm of wakefulness, recorded at a frequency of up to 6.5 Hz, however with the presence of typical physiological graphoelements of sleep. b recording of epileptiform paroxysms of the spike and sharp wave type, with generalized projection, with anterior accentuation, occurring in rhythmic bursts of short duration of 3 to 4 seconds. the paroxysms are followed by delta waves and, occasionally, rhythmic activity in the beta range of short duration of less than 1 second, which also occurred preceding the bursts of paroxysms, as well as in an isolated episode during drowsiness. c outbreaks of generalized delta activity, with bifrontal accentuation, the same projections as the paroxysms, also occurring exclusively during sleep. note: [person] presented stereotyped cephalic lateralization and oromandibular movements during wakefulness, however, without electrographic correlation with ictal patterns. conclusion and electroclinical correlation: the electroencephalogram was abnormal. the findings are compatible with diffuse encephalopathy and generalized epilepsy. computed tomography of the skull 11/12: no relevant alterations; computed tomography of the chest 11/12: no signs of an infectious process; cerebrospinal fluid 13/12: 1 cell; 0 red blood cells; glucose: 96; protein: non-reactive; chloride: 125; lactate: 1.91; transthoracic echocardiography 23/12: no signs of vegetation. no other alterations. cultures: tracheal aspirate: 12/27: enterobacter cloacae complex sensitive to meropenem 12/19: negative 12/12: staphylococcus aureus oxas resistant to clindamycin 01/07: staphylococcus epidermididis oxar blood culture: 12/27: negative so far 12/19: staphylococcus hominis 12/13: negative 01/07: 01/16: pseudomonas aeroginosas sensitive to ciprofloxacin, cephalosporin and aminoglycoside urine culture: 12/27: negative 01/07: negative venous catheter: 12/27: negative 12/19: corynebacterium sensitive to vancomycin and teicoplanin 01/09: staphylococcus epidermidis oxar cerebrospinal fluid: 12/13: micrococcus sp antibiotic therapy: current: ceftazidime d0 01/19 pseudomonas bloodstream infection. AEDC follow-up appointments: 02/02 schedule to complete antibiotic therapy directed at pseudomonas bloodstream infection: using ceftazidime d3, maintain for 7-10 days: currently clinically stable, cpr falling, last 2.5 AEDC: 02/02/22 maintain current antiepileptic drugs until follow-up appointment: phenytoin 100 mg 12/12h phenobarbital 100 mg 12/12h topiramate 100 100 200 clobazam 20 mg 8/8h lamotrigine 100 100 200 I renew prescriptions from [organization] regarding deep vein thrombosis: I prescribe rivaroxaban 20 mg/d, I provide a prescription for 6 months. I request follow-up in the network. Follow-up by physiotherapy at the CER: difficulty walking, associated with equine feet. Wheelchair, bath and diaper report: already delivered. Treatment for scabies with ivermectin was carried out on 01/17, repeat in 7 days. Regular general condition, acyanotic, anicteric, hydrated, afebrile. Cardiac auscultation: regular heart rhythm in 2t, normal sound sounds, no audible murmurs. Respiratory auscultation: vesicular breath sounds in both hemithorax, no adventitious sounds. Globular abdomen, bowel sounds, depressed and no signs of defense. Warm extremities, capillary refill time less than 3s, free calves Glasgow 14, isochoric and photoreactive pupils, no pupillary hippus, no stigmata of crisis. Can raise all 4 limbs and hold them against gravity. Understands and obeys commands. Equine feet bilaterally.

discharge_summary: admission: 02/06/2020, discharge: 12/06/2020, stay: 09 d 10 h, location: ward, payer: sus. discharge report [person], 31 years old, born and raised in [address], married, {omitted} at [organization]. date of admission to emergency unit 02/06, hospitalization summary: patient with no known comorbidities or addictions, with severe dry cough, pain in the left hemithorax and decline in general condition that started on 05/20, progressively worsening. sought medical help at the emergency care unit on 01/05 and 02/05 and was released with symptoms. due to persistent complaints, sought consultation with [person], when desaturation and signs of cor pulmonale were evidenced upon pocus according to information from [person]. The patient was referred to our service in poor general condition, hypotensive, with respiratory failure and using a 15 l/min non-rebreathing mask. Orotracheal intubation and intensive care were performed. Pulmonary thromboembolism was ruled out and bilateral pulmonary opacities suggestive of an infectious process were identified. Ceftriaxone, clindamycin, and clarithromycin were started on 6/3 and transitioned to piperacillin, tazobactam, and vancomycin on 6/5 due to septic shock, maintained until 6/12. Vasoactive drugs and neuromuscular blockade were maintained until 6/4. Sedation was discontinued on 6/7, when he was extubated without complications. The patient showed significant clinical, laboratory, and radiological improvements. He was discharged from hospital on 6/12, with guidance on warning signs and symptoms, prescription of symptomatic medications, and referral for follow-up at a primary health care unit. cultures: 04/06 negative urine culture 05/06/23 negative blood culture ongoing antibiotic therapy: ceftriaxone 03/06 to 05/06 clindamycin 03/06 to 05/06 clarithromycin 03/06 to 05/06 piperacillin tazobactam 05/06 to 12/06 vancomycin 05/06 to 12/06 previous devices: orotracheal tube 03 to 07/06 central venous catheter left internal jugular vein 03 to 11/06 intensive care unit: vasoactive drug 03 to 04/06 orotracheal intubation 03 to 07/06 neuromuscular blocker 03 to 04/06 sedation 03 to 07/06 personal history: denies known comorbidities denies known allergies habits: social drinker denies smoking denies drug use of illicit drugs medications in continuous use: ø. complementary exams: chest tomography 03/06 without images of pulmonary artery filling failure. bilateral consolidative opacities with air bronchograms and angiograms between pleural cavities: without effusions or thickening. warning signs and symptoms: intense pain high fever shortness of breath, rapid breathing, shortness of breath, fatigue intense cough with phlegm guidelines after discharge: follow-up in [organization], where to consider a new chest tomography for follow-up vaccination update symptomatic medications if necessary.

discharge_summary: date of admission: 10/04 on d11 of i mcbad and d5 of filgrastim d1 on 09/24 date of discharge: 11/03 reason for admission: treatment of bacterial and fungal endocarditis. admission: 10/04/2022, discharge: 11/04/2022, stay: 01 m 23 h, location: ward, payer: sus. case report: refractory multiple myeloma iga lambda a vi vcd iss without b2mgb/ds iiia diagnosis {omitted} relapse: anemia elevated iga and lambda pleural effusion with cytology 41% atypical plasma cells extramedullary plasmacytoma abdomen and pleura pleural biopsy 04/22: cells with scant eosinophilic cytoplasm and small, round, hyperchromatic nuclei at the cell periphery. ihq: strong and demarcated expression of cd 56, cd 138, and lambda plasmacytoid differentiation. kappa. ki67: 95%. diagnosis: plasmacytoma, multiple myeloma. abdominal biopsy 04/22: plasma cells infiltrating skeletal muscle tissue. frequent mitotic figures. no necrosis. ihq: cd138, cd56, lambda, kappa. pmo 04/16/21: diluted in sp. sv hypocellular. sb normocellular with preserved maturation. sm megakaryocytes absent in smear bmo 04/16: 35% cellularity. no neoplastic infiltration in the sample. tomography myeloma protocol 02/15/2022: awaiting report transthoracic echocardiography 04/22: ejection fraction 65% mild tricuspid regurgitation, psap 47. 2020 serologies: negative ecog: 1 previous chemotherapies: i vtd pace 07/31/2020 vi vtd d1 10/07/2020 to d1 03/10/2021 while awaiting krd disease progression previous therapeutic schedule krd total of xviii cycles [person]: performed v cycles, with disease progression emergence of plasmacytomas new treatment schedule, as discussed with [person] on 10/23: performance of mcbad for 2 to 2 cycles, while defining a new therapy. d1 i mcbad 09/24. examinations carried out during hospitalization: head tomography 05/10 done in the context of lowered level of consciousness, thrombocytopenia, bleeding ruled out. transthoracic echocardiography 10/08: preserved LVSD subjective s 8 pp 8 LVDD 45 it mild psap 50 mmhg rectification of the septum in the shape of a d extracardiac structure compressing the left atrium moderately depressed RVSD fac 20% transthoracic echocardiography 10/19: fe 62% LVDD 46 s 9.5 pp 9 filamentous images adhered to the atrial face measuring the largest 4 mm suggestive of mild IM vegetation, cultures: blood culture 10/04: staphylococcus mitis 2 samples blood culture 10/08: candida tropicalis sensitive to ketoconazole and amphotericin B micafungin and caspofungin not tested, blood culture 10/12: staphylococcus epidermidis 1 sample after 43 hours considered as a contaminant, antibiotic therapy used: cefepime: 10/04 10/05. escalated to 11/05 due to growth of streptococcus mittis in blood culture on 11/04 meropenem 10/05 10/20 vancomycin 10/05 11/03 micafungin 10/10 evaluation of other specialties: in medical records. I performed reassessment tests for the disease on the day of hospital discharge. I prescribe SLOK K 1 tablet every 12 hours. Please, whoever evaluates her at the blood center, checks the need to maintain replacement, advises warning signs and to contact the [organization] team if necessary. I request a purchase order for vorizonazole for secondary prophylaxis as instructed by the [organization] team. I schedule a transesophageal echocardiogram for 11/24. I leave pending tests to monitor eosinophilia and GGT changes, atrial fibrillation that, together with the rash presented after vancomycin on 10/31, raised the diagnostic hypothesis of DRESS syndrome by the dermatologist. Despite this hypothesis, [person] showed complete improvement of the rash and a decrease in the eosinophil count. Therefore, we opted for discharge due to low clinical suspicion at the time. I performed reassessment tests for the disease on the day of hospital discharge. hospitalization summary: [person] admitted on 10/04 on d11 of i mcbad d5 of [person] from [organization]. attended a consultation for clinical and laboratory evaluation after hospitalization 09/21 - 10/01. While waiting to be called for a consultation, she developed tremors and an increase in body temperature (pre-consultation temperature 35.6 during tremors 37.3). Due to neutropneic, she was admitted for treatment of febrile neutropenia with immediate initiation of cefepime. She was hospitalized from 09/21 to 10/01 due to dyspnea, when an extensive right lung lesion was identified, with extrinsic compression of the superior vena cava and right atrium. On September 24, the MCBAD regimen was initiated, but during the night of that date, he developed acute pulmonary edema (fluid overload), which resolved after noninvasive ventilation and furosemide. He remained in the intensive care unit for 3 days. He was discharged to the ward and, from there, to [address]. He underwent a control tomography on September 29, which showed complete resolution of compression and reduction of lung injury. After one day of hospitalization, on 10/05, she presented septic shock with need for vasoactive drugs and decreased level of consciousness, being referred to [organization], where she was hospitalized until 10/12. On 10/10, cultures with growth of yeast-like fungi were seen in blood culture 1 sample after 7:00 p.m. Candida tropicalis. Contacted [organization] and started on micafungin 100 mg 1x/day, as well as fungemia protocol, removal of central access and PIA devices, implantation of peripherally inserted central catheter and collection of catheter tip. In addition to abdominal and fundus ultrasound. The transthoracic echocardiogram showed no evidence of vegetations on examination. Therefore, transthoracic echocardiography was performed on 10/19 with the presence of filamentous images in the mitral valve suggestive of infectious vegetation, associated with mild mitral insufficiency, confirming the diagnostic hypothesis of bacterial and fungal endocarditis. Discussed with [person] from [organization] on 10/18, who advised to maintain micafungin because most Candida tropicalis are sensitive. Chest tomography was repeated on 10/18, showing control of multiple myeloma with extensive bone and right pleural disease, with disease stability in relation to 09/29 and pulmonary opacities including nodules, with the main suspicion of infectious alteration being septic embolism or fungal disease. In discussion with the [organization] team and rediscussed with [organization], we were advised to maintain antibiotics for 4 weeks from the start of treatment and not from the culture on 10/05/21 and antifungal for 6 weeks from 10/10/21. After the 6 weeks, repeat the echocardiogram and continue oral voriconazole for an indefinite period of time. Candida tropicalis is resistant to fluco and intermediate to voriconazole, given that there is no surgical plan for removal of vegetation of possible fungal etiology. On 10/31, the patient presented a skin rash with no hemodynamic repercussions and no warning signs. The hypothesis of Dress syndrome was raised, but [person] showed improvement on 11/4 with improvement in eosinophilia. discharged on 11/04/21, hemodynamically stable, eupneic, afebrile since 10/15, after finishing intravenous vancomycin with a schedule to follow-up appointment daily for infusion of micafungin 100 mg/day at the hospital on the scheduled end date of 11/21, as well as a scheduled follow-up appointment at [organization] for 11/08 to re-discuss the therapeutic schedule and arrange for the next lines of daratunumab chemotherapy.
question: ꯑꯩ ꯑꯀꯛꯅꯕ ꯃꯔꯝ ꯈꯔꯒꯤꯗꯃꯛ ꯂꯥꯌꯦꯡꯁꯪꯗ ꯄꯨꯈꯠꯄ ꯇꯥꯈꯤ꯫

Please, whoever evaluates her at the blood center, checks the need to maintain replacement, advises warning signs and to contact the [organization] team if necessary. I request a purchase order for vorizonazole for secondary prophylaxis as instructed by the [organization] team. I schedule a transesophageal echocardiogram for 11/24. I leave pending tests to monitor eosinophilia and GGT changes, atrial fibrillation that, together with the rash presented after vancomycin on 10/31, raised the diagnostic hypothesis of DRESS syndrome by the dermatologist. Despite this hypothesis, [person] showed complete improvement of the rash and a decrease in the eosinophil count. Therefore, we opted for discharge due to low clinical suspicion at the time. I performed reassessment tests for the disease on the day of hospital discharge. hospitalization summary: [person] admitted on 10/04 on d11 of i mcbad d5 of [person] from [organization]. attended a consultation for clinical and laboratory evaluation after hospitalization 09/21 - 10/01. While waiting to be called for a consultation, she developed tremors and an increase in body temperature (pre-consultation temperature 35.6 during tremors 37.3). Due to neutropneic, she was admitted for treatment of febrile neutropenia with immediate initiation of cefepime. She was hospitalized from 09/21 to 10/01 due to dyspnea, when an extensive right lung lesion was identified, with extrinsic compression of the superior vena cava and right atrium. On September 24, the MCBAD regimen was initiated, but during the night of that date, he developed acute pulmonary edema (fluid overload), which resolved after noninvasive ventilation and furosemide. He remained in the intensive care unit for 3 days. He was discharged to the ward, and from there, to [address]. He underwent a control tomography on September 29, which showed complete resolution of compression and reduction of lung injury. After one day of hospitalization, on 10/05, she presented septic shock with need for vasoactive drugs and decreased level of consciousness, being referred to [organization], where she was hospitalized until 10/12. On 10/10, cultures with growth of yeast-like fungi were seen in blood culture 1 sample after 7:00 p.m. Candida tropicalis. Contacted [organization] and started on micafungin 100 mg 1x/day, as well as fungemia protocol, removal of central access and PIA devices, implantation of peripherally inserted central catheter and collection of catheter tip. In addition to abdominal and fundus ultrasound. The transthoracic echocardiogram showed no evidence of vegetations on examination. Therefore, transthoracic echocardiography was performed on 10/19 with the presence of filamentous images in the mitral valve suggestive of infectious vegetation, associated with mild mitral insufficiency, confirming the diagnostic hypothesis of bacterial and fungal endocarditis. Discussed with [person] from [organization] on 10/18, who advised to maintain micafungin because most Candida tropicalis are sensitive. Chest tomography was repeated on 10/18, showing control of multiple myeloma with extensive bone and right pleural disease, with disease stability in relation to 09/29 and pulmonary opacities including nodules, with the main suspicion of infectious alteration being septic embolism or fungal disease. In discussion with the [organization] team and rediscussed with [organization], we were advised to maintain antibiotics for 4 weeks from the start of treatment and not from the culture on 10/05/21 and antifungal for 6 weeks from 10/10/21. After the 6 weeks, repeat the echocardiogram and continue oral voriconazole for an indefinite period of time. Candida tropicalis is resistant to fluco and intermediate to voriconazole, given that there is no surgical plan for removal of vegetation of possible fungal etiology. On 10/31, the patient presented a skin rash with no hemodynamic repercussions and no warning signs. The hypothesis of Dress syndrome was raised, but [person] showed improvement on 11/4 with improvement in eosinophilia. discharged on 11/04/21, hemodynamically stable, eupneic, afebrile since 10/15, after finishing intravenous vancomycin with a schedule to follow-up appointment daily for infusion of micafungin 100 mg/day at the hospital on the scheduled end date of 11/21, as well as a scheduled follow-up appointment at [organization] for 11/08 to re-discuss the therapeutic schedule and arrange for the next lines of daratunumab chemotherapy.

discharge_summary: admission: 09/01/2020, discharge: 09/17/2020, stay: 16 d 13 h, location: ward, payer: SUS. A 67-year-old patient with a history of overweight, smoking, and major depression was admitted on 09/01 with a perforative acute abdomen, diagnosed after examinations. On the evening of 08/31, she sought care with abdominal pain, general malaise, and dyspnea. She had undergone hysterectomy on 08/30. On 09/01, she underwent exploratory laparotomy with a finding of intestinal perforation, with a suture of the lesion and placement of a peritoneostomy. She developed severe circulatory shock, probably due to peritonitis from contamination of the abdominal cavity, and antibiotic treatment was promptly started. She was re-addressed on 09/06, where an appendectomy and abdominal wall closure were performed. On 09/07, the patient's ventilatory status began to worsen, and a chest tomography scan was performed on 09/08, revealing low-load pulmonary embolism (5%) in addition to pneumonia. A multiresistant germ was isolated in a lung culture, with specific treatment directed at the patient. Given the clinical progression, a tracheostomy was indicated due to the need for prolonged mechanical ventilation. On 09/15, {omitted} prolonged cardiopulmonary arrest was reversed after approximately 20 minutes. The patient follow-up appointmented to the intensive care unit after the procedure, with mydriatic pupils and absence of reflexes. On 09/17, a computed tomography scan of the skull was performed, revealing anoxic-ischemic encephalopathy. Tests were performed to confirm brain death, which was confirmed on {omitted}. Perforating acute abdomen. 09/01: computed tomography of the abdomen and pelvis: pneumoperitoneum, ascites, signs of peritonitis, parietal hyperalces and edema of the loops 09/01: computed tomography of the chest, pulmonary congestion, cardiomegaly, bilateral pleural effusion, opacities suggestive of an inflammatory or infectious process 09/08: computed tomography of the chest, pulmonary thromboembolism with 5% embolic burden 09/17: computed tomography of the skull. 09/01: exploratory laparotomy, sigmoid suture, creation of peritoneostomy 09/06: review, touch-ups on previous surgery with appendectomy and closure of the abdominal wall 09/15: tracheostomy 09/15: bilateral chest drainage. death.

discharge_summary: admission: 09/01/2020, discharge: 09/17/2020, stay: 16 d 13 h, location: ward, payer: SUS. A 67-year-old patient with a history of overweight, smoking, and major depression was admitted on 09/01 with a perforative acute abdomen, diagnosed after examinations. On the evening of 08/31, she sought care with abdominal pain, general malaise, and dyspnea. She had undergone hysterectomy on 08/30. On 09/01, she underwent exploratory laparotomy with a finding of intestinal perforation, with a suture of the lesion and placement of a peritoneostomy. She developed severe circulatory shock, probably due to peritonitis from contamination of the abdominal cavity, and antibiotic treatment was promptly started. She was re-addressed on 09/06, where an appendectomy and abdominal wall closure were performed. On 09/07, the patient's ventilatory status began to worsen, and a chest tomography scan was performed on 09/08, revealing low-load pulmonary embolism (5%) in addition to pneumonia. A multiresistant germ was isolated in a lung culture, with specific treatment directed at the patient. Given the clinical progression, a tracheostomy was indicated due to the need for prolonged mechanical ventilation. On 09/15, {omitted} prolonged cardiopulmonary arrest was reversed after approximately 20 minutes. The patient follow-up appointmented to the intensive care unit after the procedure, with mydriatic pupils and absence of reflexes. On 09/17, a computed tomography scan of the skull was performed, revealing anoxic-ischemic encephalopathy. Tests were performed to confirm brain death, which was confirmed on {omitted}. Perforating acute abdomen. 09/01: computed tomography of the abdomen and pelvis: pneumoperitoneum, ascites, signs of peritonitis, parietal hyperalces and edema of the loops 09/01: computed tomography of the chest, pulmonary congestion, cardiomegaly, bilateral pleural effusion, opacities suggestive of an inflammatory or infectious process 09/08: computed tomography of the chest, pulmonary thromboembolism with 5% embolic burden 09/17: computed tomography of the skull. 09/01: exploratory laparotomy, sigmoid suture, creation of peritoneostomy 09/06: review, touch-ups on previous surgery with appendectomy and closure of the abdominal wall 09/15: tracheostomy 09/15: bilateral chest drainage. death.

discharge_summary: 1 severe acute respiratory syndrome, due to coronavirus. 2 new septic shock 01/14, fever hypotension, 3 acneiform eruption secondary to corticosteroid therapy, 4 pneumomediastinum airway injury? subcutaneous emphysema after depronation worsening ventilatory status, 5 new septic shock on 01/24 start of vasoactive drug, leukocytosis, 6 reactive adrenal insufficiency? hyperkalemia hyponatremia shock. admission: 01/06/2020, discharge: 03/03/2020, stay: 01 m 24 d 18 h, location: ward, payer: sus. clinical history [person] reports that he started with headache, myalgia and dry cough on 12/28, persisting with the same until 12/31, when he sought care and was prescribed prednisone, azithromycin, zinc and symptomatics. [person] started taking prescribed medications and on 02/01 he started with a fever, having performed a PCR for coronavirus with no result yet. On 03/01 he presented respiratory discomfort, having sought care on 04/01, when antibiotic therapy was changed to intravenous; the family member does not know which medication, however, there was no indication for hospital admission. [person] persisted with respiratory discomfort, having been hospitalized in the early hours of the same day. Emergency care unit report of oxygen saturation of 88% on room air, progressively worsening. He was admitted to the emergency unit on 06/01 with severe pulmonary involvement on chest x-ray, and was continued on antibiotic therapy initiated in the emergency care unit, ceftriaxone daily on 05/01 and prophylactic dexamethasone and enoxaparin initiated. He was admitted to [organization] on 07/01, requiring orotracheal intubation and central venous catheterization. He presented septic shock on 14/01, and his antibiotic regimen was changed. He remained in bed at [organization]. He developed new septic shock on 24/01, and began using fluconazole for fungal coverage. He developed pneumomediastinum on 26/01 due to airway injury, and underwent conservative treatment. He underwent tracheostomy on 29/01. He presented reactive adrenal insufficiency and acneiform rash related to corticosteroid therapy, in addition to diarrhea treated empirically with the hypothesis of pseudomembranous colitis. Acinetobacter baumanii was isolated in the tracheal aspirate, but was not treated due to the lack of clinical repercussion. answer: ꯃꯍꯥꯛ ꯑꯁꯤ 'ꯐꯥꯏꯕ꯭ꯔꯣꯁ꯭ꯀꯣꯞ'ꯇ ꯂꯩꯔꯝꯃꯤ, ꯑꯃꯁꯨꯡ ꯂꯥꯏꯐꯝ ꯅꯥꯗꯕ ꯑꯣꯏꯔꯝꯃꯤ꯫ ꯏꯪ ꯲꯰꯱꯰ꯒꯤ ꯑꯣꯐ ꯃꯥꯔꯆ ꯳ꯗ ꯃꯍꯥꯛꯄꯨ ꯗꯤꯀꯦꯅꯨꯂꯦꯁꯟ (ꯇ꯭ꯌꯨꯕ ꯂꯧꯊꯣꯛꯄ) ꯇꯧꯈꯤ꯫ ꯗꯤꯁꯆꯥꯔꯖ ꯇꯧꯔꯕ ꯃꯇꯨꯡꯗ, 'ꯇ꯭ꯔꯥꯀꯤꯑꯣꯁ꯭ꯇꯣꯃꯤ' ꯗ꯭ꯔꯦꯁꯁꯤꯡ ꯁꯤꯖꯤꯟꯅꯗꯨꯅ ꯊꯤꯡꯖꯤꯟꯈꯤ꯫

discharge_summary: 1 severe acute respiratory syndrome, due to coronavirus. 2 new septic shock 01/14, fever hypotension, 3 acneiform eruption secondary to corticosteroid therapy, 4 pneumomediastinum airway injury? subcutaneous emphysema after depronation worsening ventilatory status, 5 new septic shock on 01/24 start of vasoactive drug, leukocytosis, 6 reactive adrenal insufficiency? hyperkalemia hyponatremia shock. admission: 01/06/2020, discharge: 03/03/2020, stay: 01 m 24 d 18 h, location: ward, payer: sus. clinical history [person] reports that he started with headache, myalgia and dry cough on 12/28, persisting with the same until 12/31, when he sought care and was prescribed prednisone, azithromycin, zinc and symptomatics. [person] started taking prescribed medications and on 02/01 he started with a fever, having performed a PCR for coronavirus with no result yet. On 03/01 he presented respiratory discomfort, having sought care on 04/01, when antibiotic therapy was changed to intravenous; the family member does not know which medication, however, there was no indication for hospital admission. [person] persisted with respiratory discomfort, having been hospitalized in the early hours of the same day. Emergency care unit report of oxygen saturation of 88% on room air, progressively worsening. He was admitted to the emergency unit on 06/01 with severe pulmonary involvement on chest x-ray, and was continued on antibiotic therapy initiated in the emergency care unit, ceftriaxone daily on 05/01 and prophylactic dexamethasone and enoxaparin initiated. He was admitted to [organization] on 07/01, requiring orotracheal intubation and central venous catheterization. He presented septic shock on 14/01, and his antibiotic regimen was changed. He remained in bed at [organization]. He developed new septic shock on 24/01, and began using fluconazole for fungal coverage. He developed pneumomediastinum on 26/01 due to airway injury, and underwent conservative treatment. He underwent tracheostomy on 29/01. He presented reactive adrenal insufficiency and acneiform rash related to corticosteroid therapy, in addition to diarrhea treated empirically with the hypothesis of pseudomembranous colitis. Acinetobacter baumanii was isolated in the tracheal aspirate, but was not treated due to the lack of clinical repercussion. He presented progressive clinical improvement and was transferred to [organization], where he remained stable. He underwent fibroscopy and was evaluated by speech therapy on 02/03, with no residual airway injury identified and a soft diet was released. He was decannulated on 03/03, remaining eupneic and in condition to be discharged. Good general condition, alert, acyanotic, anicteric, afebrile, Glasgow 15, oxygen saturation 94% in room air with capped tracheostomy, respiratory rate 28 inspirations per minute, muscle strength grade 4 in upper and lower limbs, regular heart rhythm in two beats, normal sound sounds without murmurs. Heart rate 76, vesicular breath sounds present, symmetrical, without adventitious sounds, without use of accessory muscles. Flaccid, flat abdomen, painless to palpation, without masses or visceromegaly. Extremities: palpable peripheral pulses, without edema, absence of swelling of the calves. Presence of pressure ulcer in the left lower limb, without signs of infection. Tracheostomy fibroscopy. I advise [person] on outpatient follow-up visits for: head and neck surgery on 03/15 speech therapy on 03/25 reassessment of diet physiatry to be scheduled I advise [person] on home care for tracheostomy orifice, diet, exercise and care. I prescribe symptomatic medications. Aminc, head and neck surgery, speech therapy, physiatry. Good general condition, slim, conscious and oriented, moving all 4 limbs actively with grade 4 muscle strength, still not able to walk alone. Tracheostomy orifice occluded with dressing and eating a soft diet. No pain complaints.

discharge_summary: 1. pneumonia, pulmonary metastasis? negative external rt pcr on 06/21 verified by surveillance on 06/23 2. syncope to be clarified neurocardiogenic? investigation suspended 3. consumptive syndrome due to duodenal papilla neoplasia. admission: 06/23/2020, discharge: 06/30/2020, stay: 07 d 05 h, location: ward, payer: sus. history of current illness admission: [person] referred from the emergency care unit, where he was hospitalized for 4 days. reports that 3 days ago he had a sudden episode of loss of consciousness, not preceded by prodromes, with follow-up appointment after a few seconds. level of consciousness without dysfunctions afterwards, without release of sphincters. reports only significant asthenia and fatigue associated. had 2 of these episodes on this day. had already had another similar syncope 20 days ago. He had several episodes of vomiting, which started 5 days ago and improved 2 days ago. His family called [organization] due to his condition. During the evaluation by the transport team, [person] reported an episode of fever (38.3 °C) and dry cough since 06/10. During hospitalization at [organization], he was given antibiotic therapy and referred [person] to our services. His syncope did not recur. He reported diarrhea for 15 days and improvement for 3 days, which is why his chemotherapy cycle was suspended. Upon admission, [person] was hemodynamically stable, breathing with a mask with a reservoir at 10 L/min, without respiratory distress, and denying any complaints at the moment. He is afebrile. Edema of the lower limbs, crackles, and reduced vesicular breath sounds on the left. [person] was pale and emaciated. No relevant results. Pleural fluid puncture and chest drain. Pneumonia, no pending tests. Antibiotic therapy: cefepime and clarithromycin. [person] evolves into death.

question: ꯑꯩꯍꯥꯛꯄꯨ COVID-19 ꯅ ꯅꯥꯔꯕꯔꯥ?
answer: ꯁꯨꯟꯗꯔꯒꯤ ꯋꯥꯀꯠ ꯑꯗꯨꯗ ꯅꯍꯥꯛꯀꯤ ꯑꯥꯔ.ꯇꯤ.-ꯄꯤ.ꯁꯤ.ꯑꯥꯔ.ꯒꯤ ꯔꯤꯖꯜꯠ ꯑꯗꯨ ꯏꯪ ꯲꯰꯱꯶/꯲꯱ꯗ ꯅꯦꯒꯦꯇꯤꯕ ꯑꯣꯏꯅ ꯂꯥꯛꯈꯤ, ꯃꯗꯨ ꯏꯪ ꯲꯰꯱꯶/꯲꯳ꯗ ꯊꯤꯖꯤꯟ-ꯍꯨꯝꯖꯤꯟꯕꯒꯤ ꯑꯣꯐꯤꯁꯔ ꯑꯗꯨꯅ ꯌꯦꯡꯁꯤꯟꯈꯤ ꯍꯥꯏꯅ ꯄꯜꯂꯤ꯫

discharge_summary: 1. pneumonia, pulmonary metastasis? negative external rt pcr on 06/21 verified by surveillance on 06/23 2. syncope to be clarified neurocardiogenic? investigation suspended 3. consumptive syndrome due to duodenal papilla neoplasia. admission: 06/23/2020, discharge: 06/30/2020, stay: 07 d 05 h, location: ward, payer: sus. history of current illness admission: [person] referred from the emergency care unit, where he was hospitalized for 4 days. reports that 3 days ago he had a sudden episode of loss of consciousness, not preceded by prodromes, with follow-up appointment after a few seconds. level of consciousness without dysfunctions afterwards, without release of sphincters. reports only significant asthenia and fatigue associated. had 2 of these episodes on this day. had already had another similar syncope 20 days ago. He had several episodes of vomiting, which started 5 days ago and improved 2 days ago. His family called [organization] due to his condition. During the evaluation by the transport team, [person] reported an episode of fever (38.3 °C) and dry cough since 06/10. During hospitalization at [organization], he was given antibiotic therapy and referred [person] to our services. His syncope did not recur. He reported diarrhea for 15 days and improvement for 3 days, which is why his chemotherapy cycle was suspended. Upon admission, [person] was hemodynamically stable, breathing with a mask with a reservoir at 10 L/min, without respiratory distress, and denying any complaints at the moment. He is afebrile. Edema of the lower limbs, crackles, and reduced vesicular breath sounds on the left. [person] was pale and emaciated. No relevant results. Pleural fluid puncture and chest drain. Pneumonia, no pending tests. Antibiotic therapy: cefepime and clarithromycin. [person] evolves into death.

discharge_summary: 1. coronavirus infection onset of symptoms 02/17 orotracheal intubation 02/24 extubation 03/08 2. septic shock from pulmonary focus requiring vasoactive drug resolved: antibiotic therapy: ceftriaxone 02/23 03/02 clarithromycin 04/24 03/02 corticosteroid therapy: 02/24 03/09 3. critically ill polyneuropathy grade 2 strength upper limbs and lower limbs 4. pressure injury left lower limb grade i 5. your appointment scheduled with gynecology. on 03/24 for investigation. admission: 02/24/2020, discharge: 03/19/2020, stay: 22 d 21 h, location: ward, payer: sus. current: [person] with severe acute respiratory syndrome due to coronavirus, onset of symptoms on 02/17, requiring orotracheal intubation due to respiratory failure on 02/24, due to the possibility of associated bacterial pneumonia, antibiotic therapy with ceftriaxone and clarithromycin was performed. [person] presented satisfactory clinical evolution, and extubation was performed on 03/08, without complications. Gradual weaning of oxygen therapy was performed, and oxygen was withdrawn on 03/17, at the time comfortable in room air. Due to prolonged use of neuromuscular blocker to manage mechanical ventilation, [person] developed critically ill polyneuropathy, currently with grade II motor strength in the upper and lower limbs. He also has a pressure injury in the left lower limb, which is improving, with no signs of infection. Insulin therapy was started to manage hyperglycemia, with weaning after optimization of oral metformin. It is worth mentioning that during hospitalization [person] presented abnormal vaginal bleeding, and an appointment with gynecology was scheduled for 03/24 for investigation. Good general condition, hydrated, normal color, acyanotic, anicteric, afebrile; respiratory auscultation: vesicular breath sounds with crackles on a residual basis, without respiratory distress; cardiac auscultation: regular heart rhythm in two beats; normal sound sounds without murmurs; abdomen: innocent; extremities without edema, free calves, capillary refill time less than 3 s, ulcer on the left lower limb, grade I. therapeutic plan: I speak with [person] about the importance of performing pulmonary and motor physiotherapy to manage polyneuropathy in critically ill patients. He states that he will pay for home physiotherapy. He is referred to a basic health unit: management of hypertension and diabetes. Dressing of ulcer in the left lower limb region. I prescribe a dressing with AGE. Guidance from the nutrition team regarding the home diet. I follow-up appointment to the GEAD outpatient clinic on 04/26 for clinical reassessment. I follow-up appointment to the speech therapy outpatient clinic on 05/05. I schedule a pelvic ultrasound for 03/22 and a surgical gynecology outpatient clinic for 03/24. discharge_summary: abdominal septic shock, bloodstream septic shock. admission: 03/15/2020, discharge: 03/29/2020, stay: 14 days 02 hours, location: ward: payer: sus. 1 septic shock abdominal focus decline in general condition diarrhea decreased level of consciousness onset of symptoms 03/14 orotracheal intubation on admission 03/15 due to decreased level of consciousness antibiotic therapy: meropenem din 03/15 2 atrial fibrillation [person] with irregular rhythm on admission despite no record of the comorbidity in the medical record, {person} of [person] confirms previous diagnosis of atrial fibrillation, electrocardiogram admission 03/15: atrial fibrillation 3 septic shock bloodstream 03/22: worsening of hemodynamics worsening of parameters in blood culture tests 03/22/2020: klebsiella pneumoniae. presenting complaint: decreased level of consciousness, respiratory failure, diarrhea, chest pain, history collected from [person], [person] and [person]: [person] observed a decreased level of consciousness this morning, with [person] aphasic, and presenting worsening of the basal hemiplegia. She evolved with respiratory distress, and the [organization] was called to provide assistance. at the scene, the [organization] team found blood pressure of 60x0 mmhg, non-measurable oxygen saturation, capillary refill time greater than 3 s, poorly perfused extremities, glasgow 6. 1000 ml of ringer's lactate and 500 ml of sf 0.9% were infused during transport and oxygen was administered 10 l/min via mask with reservoir. Norepinephrine 20 ml/h was started while still in the ambulance shortly before being admitted to the {organization}. [person] reports that [person] has had a progressive decline in her general health and diarrhea since yesterday, with 4 voluminous, watery bowel movements, without blood or pus, after 5 days of constipation. [person] also reports that [person] complained of chest pain this morning, but was unable to detail the characteristics of the pain. They deny fever, abdominal pain, dyspnea, cough, dysuria, nausea, vomiting, or other symptoms. [person] was admitted to the lower emergency unit, glasgow 9 3 1 5, with evident respiratory distress, pulse oxygen saturation not measurable, poorly perfused, capillary refill time greater than 3 s. Orotracheal intubation was performed on admission, {omitted}. Sedation with fentanyl and midazolam was initiated. Norepinephrine was maintained at 25 ml/h 0.382 mcg/kg/min. personal history: 1 systemic arterial hypertension 2 epilepsy in AEPA follow-up 3 nucleocapsular hemorrhagic stroke ich1 / sich1 on 07/01 etiology: hypertensive, clinical: right hemiparesis, deviation of the labial rhyme to the left, confusion nihss admission 17 1b.2 / 4.2 / 5d.3 / 5e.1 / 6d.3 / 6e.2 / 8.1 / 9.1 / 10.2 previous rankin: 0 computed tomography of the skull admission: intraparenchymal thalamocapsular hemorrhage 7.7 ml CT Angiography (CTA): no stenosis or significant vascular changes identified during previous hospitalization 07/01, left hemothorax with atelectasis due to fractures of the ribs t6t11 trauma prior to hospitalization resolved with thoracic drainage fracture of the left transverse process of t7 and fractures due to demineralization from t6t11 continuous use medications: enalapril 10 mg 12/12h amlodipine 10 mg hydrochlorothiazide 25 mg carbamazepine 700 mg/day phenobarbital 100 mg/day propranolol 40 mg [person] brought, but does not know how to inform the dose, laboratory tests: 03/16 hb 12.5 ht 38 leuco 22,000 plt 282,000 na 129 k 4.6 ca 1.04 cr 1.4 lact 3.7 urine routine nitrite leuco 20,000 red blood cells 3540 granular casts 03/18: hb 11.2 ht 34 leuco 15300 plt 150000 na 134 k 3.3 cr 0.88 ur 82 lactate 2.4 pcr 23.75 ldh 821 cultures: blood culture 03/15: no growth. urine culture 03/15: no growth. tracheal aspirate 03/16: no growth. blood culture 03/22: klebsiella pneumoniae. antibiotics on admission meropenem 03/15 03/16 ceftriaxone metronidazole 03/16 03/21 meropenam vancomycin 03/22 03/27 ceftazidime avibactam 03/28 03/29 imaging tests: transthoracic echocardiogram 03/17: moderate dilation of the left atrium and mild dilation of the left atrium and ventricle. markedly depressed systolic performance of the ventricles. alterations in segmental mobility of the left ventricle. moderate mitral valve insufficiency. mild pulmonary valve insufficiency. in time, late in the afternoon, I am called to evaluate [person] in a semi-intensive bed. I find [person] monitored with orotracheal intubation and mechanical ventilation with the following vital signs on the monitor: heart rate: 0 beats per minute, no electrical activity identified by the monitor and no invasive blood pressure curve on the monitor. no signal also on pulse oximetry. I perform a physical examination with absent central pulses. I perform a physical examination with absent central pulses. I proceed with a physical examination of the trunk reflex with absence of oculocephalic reflexes, absence of corneal-palpal reflex and fixed medium pupils that do not react to light, without consensual reflex. I certify death at {omitted}. surgical tracheostomy 03/27. death.

question: ꯁꯦꯞꯇꯤꯛ ꯁꯣꯛ ꯀꯔꯤꯒꯤ ꯊꯣꯛꯏ?
answer: "সেপটিক শক অ্যাবডোমিনাল ফোকাস", "সেপটিক শক হেমাতোসিস" হায়না তাকখি। লক্ষনশিংদা "জেনারেল ৱেকনেস, ডায়রিয়া, অমসুং ক্ৰিস্চিয়ন্স হ্রাস" অমসুং "হেমোডাইনামিক ইন্সটেবিলিটি" (কমিং রেদ স্ট্রস) য়াওখি, মরম অসিনা মহাক্না "নোরএড্রিনালিন" (রেদ স্ট্রসকী হিদাক) লৌবা মথৌ তাইখি।

discharge_summary: abdominal septic shock, bloodstream septic shock. admission: 03/15/2020, discharge: 03/29/2020, stay: 14 days 02 hours, location: ward: payer: sus. 1 septic shock abdominal focus decline in general condition diarrhea decreased level of consciousness onset of symptoms 03/14 orotracheal intubation on admission 03/15 due to decreased level of consciousness antibiotic therapy: meropenem din 03/15 2 atrial fibrillation [person] with irregular rhythm on admission despite no record of the comorbidity in the medical record, {person} of [person] confirms previous diagnosis of atrial fibrillation, electrocardiogram admission 03/15: atrial fibrillation 3 septic shock bloodstream 03/22: worsening of hemodynamics worsening of parameters in blood culture tests 03/22/2020: klebsiella pneumoniae. presenting complaint: decreased level of consciousness, respiratory failure, diarrhea, chest pain, history collected from [person], [person] and [person]: [person] observed a decreased level of consciousness this morning, with [person] aphasic, and presenting worsening of the basal hemiplegia. She evolved with respiratory distress, and the [organization] was called to provide assistance. at the scene, the [organization] team found blood pressure of 60x0 mmhg, non-measurable oxygen saturation, capillary refill time greater than 3 s, poorly perfused extremities, glasgow 6. 1000 ml of ringer's lactate and 500 ml of sf 0.9% were infused during transport and oxygen was administered 10 l/min via mask with reservoir. Norepinephrine 20 ml/h was started while still in the ambulance shortly before being admitted to the {organization}. [person] reports that [person] has had a progressive decline in her general health and diarrhea since yesterday, with 4 voluminous, watery bowel movements, without blood or pus, after 5 days of constipation. [person] also reports that [person] complained of chest pain this morning, but was unable to detail the characteristics of the pain. They deny fever, abdominal pain, dyspnea, cough, dysuria, nausea, vomiting, or other symptoms. [person] was admitted to the lower emergency unit, glasgow 9 3 1 5, with evident respiratory distress, pulse oxygen saturation not measurable, poorly perfused, capillary refill time greater than 3 s. Orotracheal intubation was performed on admission, {omitted}. Sedation with fentanyl and midazolam was initiated. Norepinephrine was maintained at 25 ml/h 0.382 mcg/kg/min. personal history: 1 systemic arterial hypertension 2 epilepsy in AEPA follow-up 3 nucleocapsular hemorrhagic stroke ich1 / sich1 on 07/01 etiology: hypertensive, clinical: right hemiparesis, deviation of the labial rhyme to the left, confusion nihss admission 17 1b.2 / 4.2 / 5d.3 / 5e.1 / 6d.3 / 6e.2 / 8.1 / 9.1 / 10.2 previous rankin: 0 computed tomography of the skull admission: intraparenchymal thalamocapsular hemorrhage 7.7 ml CT Angiography (CTA): no stenosis or significant vascular changes identified during previous hospitalization 07/01, left hemothorax with atelectasis due to fractures of the ribs t6t11 trauma prior to hospitalization resolved with thoracic drainage fracture of the left transverse process of t7 and fractures due to demineralization from t6t11 continuous use medications: enalapril 10 mg 12/12h amlodipine 10 mg hydrochlorothiazide 25 mg carbamazepine 700 mg/day phenobarbital 100 mg/day propranolol 40 mg [person] brought, but does not know how to inform the dose, laboratory tests: 03/16 hb 12.5 ht 38 leuco 22,000 plt 282,000 na 129 k 4.6 ca 1.04 cr 1.4 lact 3.7 urine routine nitrite leuco 20,000 red blood cells 3540 granular casts 03/18: hb 11.2 ht 34 leuco 15300 plt 150000 na 134 k 3.3 cr 0.88 ur 82 lactate 2.4 pcr 23.75 ldh 821 cultures: blood culture 03/15: no growth. urine culture 03/15: no growth. tracheal aspirate 03/16: no growth. blood culture 03/22: klebsiella pneumoniae. antibiotics on admission meropenem 03/15 03/16 ceftriaxone metronidazole 03/16 03/21 meropenam vancomycin 03/22 03/27 ceftazidime avibactam 03/28 03/29 imaging tests: transthoracic echocardiogram 03/17: moderate dilation of the left atrium and mild dilation of the left atrium and ventricle. markedly depressed systolic performance of the ventricles. alterations in segmental mobility of the left ventricle. moderate mitral valve insufficiency. mild pulmonary valve insufficiency. in time, late in the afternoon, I am called to evaluate [person] in a semi-intensive bed. I find [person] monitored with orotracheal intubation and mechanical ventilation with the following vital signs on the monitor: heart rate: 0 beats per minute, no electrical activity identified by the monitor and no invasive blood pressure curve on the monitor. no signal also on pulse oximetry. I perform a physical examination with absent central pulses. I perform a physical examination with absent central pulses. I proceed with a physical examination of the trunk reflex with absence of oculocephalic reflexes, absence of corneal-palpal reflex and fixed medium pupils that do not react to light, without consensual reflex. I certify death at {omitted}. surgical tracheostomy 03/27. death.

discharge_summary: 1. pneumonia, pulmonary metastasis? negative external rt pcr on 06/21 verified by surveillance on 06/23 2. syncope to be clarified neurocardiogenic? investigation suspended 3. consumptive syndrome due to duodenal papilla neoplasia. admission: 06/23/2020, discharge: 06/30/2020, stay: 07 d 05 h, location: ward, payer: sus. history of current illness admission: [person] referred from the emergency care unit, where he was hospitalized for 4 days. reports that 3 days ago he had a sudden episode of loss of consciousness, not preceded by prodromes, with follow-up appointment after a few seconds. level of consciousness without dysfunctions afterwards, without release of sphincters. reports only significant asthenia and fatigue associated. had 2 of these episodes on this day. had already had another similar syncope 20 days ago. He had several episodes of vomiting, which started 5 days ago and improved 2 days ago. His family called [organization] due to his condition. During the evaluation by the transport team, [person] reported an episode of fever (38.3 °C) and dry cough since 06/10. During hospitalization at [organization], he was given antibiotic therapy and referred [person] to our services. His syncope did not recur. He reported diarrhea for 15 days and improvement for 3 days, which is why his chemotherapy cycle was suspended. Upon admission, [person] was hemodynamically stable, breathing with a mask with a reservoir at 10 L/min, without respiratory distress, and denying any complaints at the moment. He is afebrile. Edema of the lower limbs, crackles, and reduced vesicular breath sounds on the left. [person] was pale and emaciated. No relevant results. Pleural fluid puncture and chest drain. Pneumonia, no pending tests. Antibiotic therapy: cefepime and clarithromycin. [person] evolves into death.

discharge_summary: admission: 23/02/2020, discharge: 09/03/2020, stay: 14 d, location: ward, payer: sus. [person], 65 years old, born and raised in [address], widower. problem: asthenia, worsening of basal dyspnea, drowsiness, desaturation, bladder indwelling urinary catheter with pyuria, hypotension and worsening of perfusion diagnostic hypotheses: 1. mixed shock: septic of urinary focus, weaning from norepinephrine on 25/02, cardiogenic, heart failure, due to decompensated alcoholic cardiomyopathy profile, weaning from dobutamine on 03/03 started tridil 26/02 and oral vasodilators on 27/02/2020. 2. acute kidney injury kdigo 3 creatinine: 6.57 urea: 348: acute ischemic tubular necrosis secondary to infection, SCR type 1 on renal replacement therapy since 02/23/2020. cultures: blood culture 02/23/2020: carbapenem-resistant Klebsiella pneumoniae in 2 samples at 22 and 42 h. urine culture 02/23/2020: carbapenem-resistant Klebsiella pneumoniae. history: systemic arterial hypertension, hypothyroidism? chronic liver disease, active significant alcoholism, active smoking 110 pack-years, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, presumed pulmonology evaluation on 08/18. Evolution: despite the culture showing Klebsiella pneumoniae carbapenemase, [person] showed a good clinical response to meropenem, thus concluding the use of meropenem 1000 mg 1x/day 500 mg post renal replacement therapy for 14 days dated 02/23/2020. He evolved with improvement in infectious parameters, afebrile, with no genitourinary or cardiorespiratory complaints. Latest laboratory tests: Hb: 12.4 ht: 37 platelets: 123 gb: 7.5 without deviation to the left. Undergoing follow-up with nephrology, daily hemodialysis was performed. Schedule: with completion of antibiotic therapy and maintenance of improvement in clinical parameters, discharged from [organization] on 03/09/2020. Scheduled by nephrology for follow-up on acute dialysis on Mondays, Wednesdays and Fridays, in the first shift.

[person], 65 years old, born and raised in [address], widower. problem: asthenia, worsening of basal dyspnea, drowsiness, desaturation, bladder indwelling urinary catheter with pyuria, hypotension and worsening of perfusion diagnostic hypotheses: 1. mixed shock: septic of urinary focus, weaning from norepinephrine on 25/02, cardiogenic, heart failure, due to decompensated alcoholic cardiomyopathy profile, weaning from dobutamine on 03/03 started tridil 26/02 and oral vasodilators on 27/02/2020. 2. acute kidney injury kdigo 3 creatinine: 6.57 urea: 348: acute ischemic tubular necrosis secondary to infection, SCR type 1 on renal replacement therapy since 02/23/2020. cultures: blood culture 02/23/2020: carbapenem-resistant Klebsiella pneumoniae in 2 samples at 22 and 42 h. urine culture 02/23/2020: carbapenem-resistant Klebsiella pneumoniae. history: systemic arterial hypertension, hypothyroidism? chronic liver disease, active significant alcoholism, active smoking 110 pack-years, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, presumed pulmonology evaluation on 08/18. Evolution: despite the culture showing Klebsiella pneumoniae carbapenemase, [person] showed a good clinical response to meropenem, thus concluding the use of meropenem 1000 mg 1x/day 500 mg post renal replacement therapy for 14 days dated 02/23/2020. Latest laboratory tests: Hb: 12.4 ht: 37 platelets: 123 gb: 7.5 without deviation to the left. Undergoing follow-up with nephrology, daily hemodialysis was performed. discharge_summary: id: [person], 49 years old, from [address], born in {city}. admission 17/11/2020 1. severe alcoholic hepatitis with child b7 meld encephalopathy on the 9th abdominal ultrasound 11/17 hepatomegaly and diffuse increased liver echogenicity, suggestive of fatty disease. gallstones. mild splenomegaly. last alcoholic libation in mid-november 2. fever probable urinary focus urine culture 12/30/2020 multisensitive escherichia coli ceftriaxone in: 12/30/2020 complications resolved with hospitalization:. chronic diarrhea associated with alcohol. respiratory failure nosocomial pneumonia 12/07: fever, tachypnea, requiring oxygen chest tomography 12/06/2020: pulmonary opacities with an organizing pneumonia pattern that may correspond to an inflammatory or infectious process, which may present with viral pneumonia, involving 25-30% of the parenchyma. bilateral pleural effusion. severe coronary atheromatosis rapid coronavirus test 12/08/2020 negative coronavirus PCR 12/07/2020: inconclusive, orotracheal intubation for acute respiratory failure on 12/13 extubation on 12/23 performed 7 days of meropenem termination 12/15, personal history: mood disorder? systemic arterial hypertension, obesity, diabetes mellitus? dyslipidemia, epilepsy? Habits: Active alcoholism 67 cans of beer per day and half a liter of distilled spirits on weekends for 25 years, active tobacco smoking 12.5 pack-years Other relevant tests Abdominal ultrasound 09/04 External liver with blunt edges, gallbladder without alterations Diffuse infiltration of the hepatic parenchyma, storage disease Chronic liver disease and hepatomegaly Portal hypertension Liposubstituted pancreas, enlarged lymph nodes Sparse colonic diverticula, no inflammatory signs Gastric biopsy 11/19: fragments of gastric mucosa Antral and body patterns, fundus with mild and inactive chronic gastritis. Helicobacter pylori research was negative in this material Absence of signs of intestinal metaplasia, epithelial dysplasia and malignancy. medications for continuous use at home: losartan 50 mg 100 sertraline 100 mg 100 simvastatin 20 mg 001 clonazepam 5 mg 001 valproic acid does not know the dose phenobarbital 1 tablet at night fenofibrate complex b current previous antibiotic therapy piperacillin tazobactam 11/29 12/08 amoxicillin clavulanate 11/19 11/22 empirical to combat helicobacter pylori metronidazole 11/19 11/25 nitazoxanide 11/18 11/20 meropenem in: 12/08 12/15 ceftriaxone in 12/30. admission: 11/17/2020, discharge: 01/05/2021, stay: 01 m 18 d 12 h, location: ward, payer: sus. good general condition, pale 1 / 4, hydrated, anicteric, acyanotic, afebrile to the touch and eupneic in room air respiratory auscultation vesicular breath sounds present, reduced overall, no adventitious sounds, no signs of respiratory distress, respiratory rate 19 saturation: 97% room air cardiac auscultation: regular heart rhythm, in 2 times, no murmurs heart rate: 8normal S1 and S2 per minute abdomen: globular, flaccid, bowel sounds, painless to superficial or deep palpation, no signs of peritoneal irritation. liver palpable 3 cm from the right costal margin, in the midclavicular line. extremities: warm and well perfused; capillary refill time less than 3 seconds; no edema or swelling of the calves. presence of ochre dermatitis on the lower limbs, with bilateral fibrous scars, without flapping pressure injury in the sacral region. discussed with [person]: we decided to discharge the patient after completing treatment for urinary tract infection by escherichia coli multis with a follow-up appointment visit on 1/17 at the gaf for reevaluation. we maintain medications in use during hospitalization. we provide guidance on warning signs. home care service sad for pressure injury care and home motor physiotherapy. good.
